I have watched No Country for Old Men three times, and I would like to share my opinion of the film. Directed and written by Joel and Ethan Coen, No Country for Old Men was released back in 2007 with a budget of 25 million dollars. The movie is based on Cormac McCarthy's 2005 novel with the same name. The film itself is a neo-western film that is rich in philosophic concepts. It is more of an experience than a movie. Every watch through left me staring off into the dark in awe. I've always been left with more questions than answers. It is an armchair philosopher's dream. 

The film takes place in Texas; it follows three men whose stories are all connected in some way. The first man is a sheriff named Ed Tom Bell. He feels as if the world around him is much more violent than it was in his father's day. Anton Chigurh strangles a deputy and kills a man on the highway for his car. Meanwhile, a hunter by the name of Llewelen Moss comes across a drug deal gone wrong. There he finds a suitcase filled with money. Down on his luck, he steals the suitcase and becomes entangled within this hunt for the suitcase. The hunter becomes the hunted as Anton Chigurh begins to track him, always hot on his heels.  

The most surprising feature of the film is the minimal dialogue and lack of soundtrack. After my first watch through, I was surprised to find this out. What takes the place of a soundtrack is the sound of wind. Personally, I never noticed this detail until my second watch. This choice of design adds to the seriousness of the movie almost to the point that an actual soundtrack would take so much away from the movie. It makes the movie feel real, almost as if I've been allowed to be a spectator in the lives of these three men. It allows you to be in the moment; the silence at times makes you feel as though Anton Chigurh is right there with you hunting both you and Llewelen. Furthermore, the minimal dialogue forces the actors to express more with their bodies and facial expressions. Instead of telling us exactly how they are thinking or what they are feeling we are forced to place ourselves in their shoes and pick up on context clues and body language.  

There is so much to unpack with this movie that there is something for everyone. From the philosophical preaching's of the Sherriff to the cinematography. Every little bit of No Country for Old Men just begs for you to analyze it. I give this movie 5/5 stars. The acting, the writing, and everything about this film exceeds expectations. I could not recommend this movie enough. This isn't a movie you sit down to watch one time. I would suggest you sit down and take the time to soak everything in. This movie isn't something to be devoured like most content in the modern era.  It's a fine wine meant to be savored and enjoyed. Maybe you don't get all the notes and nuances from your first glass, but every glass after, you will find something new and deeper.

The beauty of "No Country for Old Men" is immediately apparent, emerging from the distinct way in which the source material is translated onto the screen. One could easily imagine the Cormac McCarthy novel coming to life in front of them, duly preserving in cinematic form all of the peculiarly haunting qualities of the source's dialogue and tone. McCarthy's novels are darkly poetic and stubbornly ambiguous; willfully omitting easy clarification of potentially important plot points in favor of establishing even more critical emphases on the guiding, underlying themes. The Coen's film is true to each one of these qualities, despite the potential temptation to offer easy accessibility and resolution. They amplify, in their own innovative way, the very elements which make McCarthy's work so absorbing, disturbing and enigmatic. While this is not a film for the faint of heart, it will surely strike any serious aficionado of the Coen's as one of their most stirring and masterful works.

This film, the best of 2007, is just about perfect. From beginning to end, first frame to last, the Coen brothers never misstep. The performances are equally superb across the board, and the screenplay is crisp and deliberate. The story remains gripping and riveting throughout, the dialogue has a twangy poetry, and the philosophical undertones of Cormac McCarthy's story translate to the screen magnificently. Not a single false or bad moment. A brilliant masterpiece

The fact I'm still giving this what I consider to be a positive rating shows how much the conclusion frustrated me. This had top tier written all over it but it somehow messed it up as it went by... and I'm not usually one to dig out a film's ending.

In my defence, even some reviews (many, in fact) from people who love the film mention that the ending isn't perfect so I guess it just comes down to how the final moments sit with you. For me, evidently not good!

So why do I call it a flawed masterpiece rather than a masterpiece full stop? Well actually right up to the last twenty minutes, the film was the latter rather than the former. If the last twenty minutes had not felt like a completely different movie, it would've stayed like that. As is the case with all the Coen Brothers' movies, No Country for Old Men is very well made with impressive cinematography, editing and settings. The story is compelling, the direction superb and the script most of the time taut, funny, thrilling and exciting. Josh Brolin and Tommy Lee Jones are excellent in this film, but if I have to give an award to best performance of the film, it would be Javier Bardem in a villainous role that is menacing and chillingly effective. Overall, a great movie but due to the final twenty minutes it just loses out to that extra something. 9/10 Bethany Cox

Right out of Corman McCarthy's novel of the same name, No Country for Old Men transcends film greatness with fabolous performances and a clear pacing with expertly handled moments. The movie is of course expertly written, shot and directed in general, but coming from the greats of the Coen Brothers', that shoudn't be a surprise.

The Coen brothers have always been very special filmmakers. With The Big Lebowski and Fargo, they were already responsible for two films that had already a very strong and positive influence on society. Nothing else applies to No Country For Old Men. The crime thriller, which is very reminiscent of the Western genre, won four Oscars in 2008, including the Coen brothers for their directing and the film itself for Best Picture. The plot is about how a pensioner steals money from a cartel after a massacre in the desert and goes on the run after an attempted murder against him. In the process, he is pursued by a psychopathic hitman who is after much more than the stolen money. A veteran sheriff sets out on a trail parallel to this event.

One of the many highlights of this film are the acting performances. Josh Brolin plays the fugitive protagonist Llewelyn Moss. He thrills especially in the tense scenes when it is a matter of life or death for his character. Tommy Lee Jones as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell appears least often throughout the film and seems irrelevant for a long time, until he shows all his class at the end by losing himself in monologues that are unexpectedly profound and meaningful. Javier Bardem, however, absolutely stands out as the serial killer and pursuer of Moss, Anton Chigurh. His character is enormously intriguing despite his one-dimensionality. When he repeats himself several times in dialogues with potential victims and you don't know whether he's going to pull the trigger or not, it gives the film countless unpredictable and teeth-grinding moments.

For long stretches, No Country for Old Men feels like a thriller that leaves all possible outcomes open. The ending is then a little surprising and even seems inadequate at first. But if you think about it for a while, you realise that the Coen brothers have given the film a very sociocritical background. It is pessimistic, but realistic. How you interpret it is ultimately up to you. But when you become aware of this very subtle message, the bizarre ending suddenly makes much more sense. This realisation, the strong acting, the terrific camera work and much more make No Country for Old Men one of the most important and fascinating films of the 2000s.

With their adaptation of Cormac McCarthy's No Country for Old Men, the Coen brothers have created one of the defining American films of the early 21st century. The movie deals with a variety of themes, including fate, greed, nihilism and, perhaps most importantly, how we set our moral compass.  Early in the film, Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) stumbles across a drug deal gone bad in the middle of the desert.  He takes a case filled with money and leaves the sole survivor to die of thirst.  Later the same day, he reconsiders and returns to give the man water, thus setting into motion the chain of events. The cinematography is gorgeous, capturing the dry and raw beauty of west Texas.  The acting is uniformly top notch, especially Javier Bardem as Anton Chigurh, the killer with his own code of ethics and destined to become an icon among Hollywood villains.

The Coen Brothers' "No Country for Old Men" is a bleak, darkly comic and unsettling western that finds the filmmaking duo at the peak of their powers. With their twelfth feature, the Coen Brothers crafted a mesmerizing western that holds up today as a modern classic. Using captivating cinematography, the Coen Brothers draw viewers into a desolate world of violence. From intimate close-ups to gorgeous establishing shots, the cinematography keeps viewers immersed in the film's western setting. The Coen Brothers' decision to work without a traditional musical score is risky, but it works tremendously. The absence of music gives the film a tense and eerie atmosphere that keeps viewers engrossed. As usual, the Coen Brothers draw excellent performances from their cast. Javier Bardem delivers one of the best performances of his career as Anton Chigurh. With frightening expressions, he conveys the cruelty, intelligence and remorseless nature of a psychopathic killer. The supporting cast, which includes the heartbreaking Tommy Lee Jones, is also excellent and worthy of recognition. Although "No Country for Old Men" is undeniably unforgettable, ultimately it is not a flawless film. If there's a minor drawback to the movie, it suffers from an ambiguous ending. After building nail-biting tension for two hours, the Coen Brothers end the film on an anti-climactic note that leaves viewers with questions. Nevertheless, fans of the Coen Brothers will definitely enjoy "No Country for Old Men" and so will movie-goers seeking taut entertainment. At a time when nihilism is rarely depicted in films, it's a cautionary reminder of the dangers posed by psychopathic killers in the modern world.

Meanwhile, stoic Mexican convict Anton Chigurh (Javier Bardem) escapes from prison and follows his trails to kill him, leaving no stone unturned. While this happens, Sheriff Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) investigates the scene of the crime and laments about the progressively violent and worsening crime in society. Like most Coen pictures, the premise is about a character who enters the world of crime in suburban America only to have a dark and depressing resolution. Also, the brothers blend together the Sam Peckinpah-style violence with quirky, dry, tongue-and-cheek humor. However, No Country, albeit similar to Fargo, is more visually impressive, showing ugly scuff marks on floors, punctures on walls, scratches on the air ventilation pipes, blood on sand and gunshot wounds on skin to match with the gruesome violence or Roger Deakins's crisp, oily and often natural camerawork to emulate the film's gritty and brutally realistic tone. Also, more striking than their previous work, The Coens choose to disclude Carter Burwell's score, aside from the end credits. The disturbing absence of music, another realistic touch, creates tension and builds up Anton's quiet, calculated presence, resulting in unexpected, jolting sound cues. As far as thrillers are concerned No Country for Old Men is the best Coen Brothers film I've seen, aside from Fargo, True Grit, Barton Fink, Burn After Reading and The Ballad of Buster Scruggs.

No Country For Old Men is a movie I've thought a lot about since I've seen it. Originally I only gave it 3 stars. The ending seemed abrupt and not much was resolved, characters were killed without seeming to have fulfilled their full purpose, and *Spoiler Alert* the bad guy gets away. I was left puzzled by this conclusion and struggled to figure out what sheriff Ed Tom Bell's (Tommy Lee Jones) final lines meant, about the dream and his father. To understand them I had to look back to the very beginning, to the title actually, which describes what the movie's really about— a hostile land where there are no rules, like the old west, where the strongest and cleverest man is the victor. But it's also a real world, one of coincidence where things just happen for no reason at all. Events are not formulated to come out in a certain way to satisfy the viewer and in that the story mirrors real life. So what Bell is saying is that it's tough to live in this world and even tougher when you're weighed down by age. Life just seems to get harder as it goes on for these characters, until it ends, and for many people that's the way life is. You can never see what's coming, it may be the discovery of a bag of money or a car zipping around the corner. The characters in the movie are aware of chance as a driving factor in their lives. Anton Chigurh, played with perfect viciousness by Javier Bardem, flips a coin to let fate decide whether someone is going to live or die and he acts on what fate chooses. Josh Brolin's Llewelyn Moss is the opposite. He thinks he can take his life into his own hands after he's provided with a way of doing so, money, without acknowledging that it was chance that lead him to the money in the first place. He's wrong, of course, and must run for his life from the relentless Chigurh in one of the tensest chase sequences on film. In the end, Moss is never given a chance to reflect on the promising yet doomed hand he was dealt by fate. He's killed off screen, his body found by Bell in a motel, leaving us to wonder what ran through his mind before he died. We, along with poor Bell, are left with an unsolved case, the murderer still at large and all the loose ends left untied. Just as life is filled with coincidences it is also filled with mysteries, stories that just drop off, people that just disappear. We're left just to return to our own lives, face the problems we can solve, like Bell, and think about what happened. And that's the best thing a movie can do: make you think.

I don't usually like the Coen Brothers and I would consider Western films to be one of my least favorite genres but in between The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002) and The Life of Emile Zola (1937) this was a welcome refresher. No, I don't think it should have won Best Picture, I prefer Atonement (2007), however I will admit it is an extremely enjoyable, tense film that features a great Javier Bardem performance and some wonderful Roger Deakins cinematography. This is not a film for everybody because it does contain graphic violence and you will have to have tolerance for the Coens' self satisfied dialogue.

Sociopathic hit man Anton Chigurh, Javier Bardem, is chasing Llewellyn Moss, Josh Brolin, who has stolen a briefcase of money from drug dealers he found in the desert. It quickly emerges that Chigurh simply enjoys murdering people and we see a myriad of victims be murdered in creative ways as he pursues the crafty Moss. Moss's wife Carla Jean, Kelly McDonald, has been sent to stay with her mother but her concern for her husband increases the longer he is gone and she reaches out to Sherriff Bell, Tommy Lee Jones, who she believes can protect Moss. 

Never let it be said that the Coens don't know how to blend comedy with graphic violence and you get a lot of that here. The whole film is essentially one long chase and the directors and the screenwriter know how to keep the story engaging and interesting even as the characters would be thoroughly dislikable in a flatter film. When we witness Moss desperately trying to pull the briefcase of money out of an air duct as the unstoppable force that is Chigurh approaches it was a nail-biting moment as well as being one that elicits nervous laughter. Even the dark penultimate scene of the film has an undertone of humor to it and although I was horrified I was also tittering to myself. This blend makes the film a really fun romp but is deceptively well constructed as it is incredibly difficult to make such dark material entertaining and keep audiences engrossed.

All of the characters were very simple and they don't exactly experience arcs but I still felt myself rooting for Moss even as I was entertained by Chigurh's antics. The overacting present in all of the Coens' movies is something I have never been quite on board with and the presence of the usually wonderful McDonald giving a performance I didn't like irked me. Some humor was mined from this approach but I always find myself being more annoyed with how smug and self satisfied this seems instead of finding it funny or disturbing. Bardem is of course great as he convinces as a very creepy sociopath with his sunken face and precise delivery. If this was a foreign film maybe I would be more accepting and I do admit that what it does is very impressive because I have seen so many films fail spectacularly in trying to imitate the style of the Coen brothers.

I suppose the meaning of the film was that evil will always prevail. We see the evil figure of Chigurh triumph over all of the characters who attempt to make moral decisions in the film and it doesn't appear that his reign of terror will end any time soon. No, Moss is not perfect but he does try to be a good husband and is not as unnecessarily violent as Chigurh. It's hard to relate to the nihilistic outlook that the Coens seem to have taken here but if they are to commit to that ideology they have certainly written an ode to it in film form.

This is probably one of the most fun Best Picture winners that you could watch and at just over two hours it's fairly short. No Country for Old Men is not just a modern Western. Sure, on the surface it's a tense story of unrepentant violence. Even in that respect, it is fantastic. The performances and the cinematography alone would make this film incredible.

But there is more.

No Country for Old Men depicts a changing world. A world where violence, unmitigated and mindless, is everywhere. People die for no reason at all. The Coen brothers - and Cormack McCarthy before them - saw where the world was headed, and they saw that there was no way to stop the insanity. They were right.

The three central characters of the film represent many different things. Sheriff Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) is nostalgia. He is a remnant of the past, a vestige of an older age where people treated others with kindness. His beliefs and worldview simply cannot coexist with what the world is becoming.

Llewelyn (Josh Brolin) is everyone. He is moral ambiguity - neither evil nor good. Llewelyn represents humanity in the grand scheme of the universe. He never seems to have control over the situation, the outcome always dictated by someone or something else. He is adrift, pushed around by waves at war with each other.

Anton Chigurh is chaos. Unbridled, unrelenting, unstoppable chaos. A veritable force of nature. Fate itself. Chigurh has no conscience and no morality. Chigurh is the driving power that changes the world, and uses brutal violence to do so.

The plot of No Country for Old Men is very much about a changing world, but it is also about death. Much of the carnage is witnessed on screen, but the death of Llewelyn is not. It is quick, unexpected, and hardly noted at all. I believe that this is an example of how death comes for everyone, and you never expect it, and your death is not more meaningful or impactful than that of anyone else.

Contrary to the beliefs of Sheriff Bell, the film is quick to point out that senseless violence has always existed. Human beings have been killing each other since the dawn of time, and we will continue to do so until the planet is rid of us.

No Country for Old Men is a film that will make you think. It will make you consider the state of the world and the state of the human race. It will make you long for older days and better times.

My introduction to the Coen Brothers was through Fargo. That film made an extremely strong impression on me - it displaced The Empire Strikes Back as my favorite film with its skillful mix of comedy and drama and helped kindle my interest in the medium. I was hoping for something similar when I rented No Country for Old Men for the first time. This expectation was quickly squashed. Fargo has substantial comedic element, while No Country for Old Men, despite its occasional moments of dark comedy, is primarily a serious, rather philosophical thriller. Despite this, No Country for Old Men quickly enthralled me, albeit in a different way than Fargo, living up to its reputation as one of the best films of its decade.

No Country for Old Men, based on a novel by Cormac McCarthy is set in the deserts and towns of southwestern Texas, a setting which would perfect for a Western (a genre from which the movie clearly takes influence) if not for the fact that the film is set 100 years too late. Changing times have turned the region into a hotbed for drug smuggling and drug-related violence. Llewelyn Moss, a welder and Vietnam veteran, finds 2 million dollars at the site of a botched drug deal in the west Texas desert. This sets Anton Chigurh, a merciless hitman with a set of seemingly alien principles and a Two-Face-like penchant for deciding whether to kill people based on a coin flip, on his tail. Local sheriff Ed Tom Bell realizes the danger Moss faces and attempts to protect him, but in the process is forced to confront societal changes, more than a little depravity, and his own perceptions that America is becoming a less hospitable and more violent place.

The entire cast gives fantastic performances. Javier Bardem's performance as Anton Chigurh is probably the most celebrated, having earned the actor an Academy Award, and this acclaim is largely deserved – Bardem's performance gives the character such an intimidating air that he looks like he could beat up Darth Vader and steal his lunch money, and the exchange between his character and the proprietor of a remote gas station is positively inspired. Tommy Lee Jones and Josh Brolin, while less critically celebrated for their roles in the film, also give fantastic performances. Sheriff Bell is inseparable in my mind from Tommy Lee Jones' soft-spoken, Texas accented voice, and Josh Brolin's carefree, cavalier portrayal of Llewelyn Moss sells his extreme overconfidence in his ability to win his game of cat-and-mouse against Chigurh.

One of No Country for Old Men's central themes is fate. Anton Chigurh believes strongly in fate; in his eyes, he has no control over the deaths of people who fail his iconic coin toss despite pulling the trigger – fate decided that they wouldn't live, not him. Llewelyn Moss and his wife, Carla Jean, believe strongly in free will. Llewelyn Moss' cavalier attitude stems from his conviction that he can change the fate Chigurh has presented. The eventual triumph of one party reveals the positions of the Coen Brothers and McCarthy on the debate between determinism and free will. Sheriff Bell is isolated from the fate versus free will debate but serves to demonstrate another important theme – he is the old man mentioned in the title. Bell repeatedly reminisces over how times have changed, and America has become a country he doesn't understand. Unlike the movie's commentary on fate, the movie leaves it ambiguous as to whether Bell's statements regarding the collapse of American society since the Vietnam War are true or whether Bell's perspective has simply changed as he has gotten older.

My reviews generally focus more heavily on the concrete aspects of a film – story, acting, plot, cinematography – rather than more nebulous aspects such as symbolism and themes, but I quite enjoyed analyzing and reading interpretations of No Country for Old Men. The film seems to be written to make audiences to think more deeply about the subtext, with an ending which is more focused on resolving the themes than the fates of the surviving characters. This ending might upset some people, but I rather liked it despite being unable to conclusively state its meaning. Having not read the novel, I'm unsure how much of the ideology of the film originated in Cormac McCarthy's novel and how much originated in the Coen Brothers' screenplay, but even if the subtext was copied entirely from the novel, the Coen Brothers and their collaborators deserve high praise for creating what is likely one of the best adaptations of all time.

Joel and Ethan Coen's direct a modern Western film for adults with their neo-noir Western thriller No Country for Old Men (2007). I am happy it won Best Picture at The Oscars as The Coen Brothers deliver a hard hitting serious film similar to their early neo-noir crime dramas Blood Simple and Miller's Crossing. The Coen Brothers find the beauty in the grisly with their strikingly quiet direction. They draw out each gunfight with skillful suspense and heavy atmosphere. 

Cormac McCarthy's story is fascinating and Joel and Ethan reinvent the wheel by taking a simple narrative and adding shadows and color with their warm direction. Every moment is tense as suspense builds into a hail of bullets and air blasts. No Country for Old Men is a cool Western that grips you from the brutal opening to the endless chase of a sociopath seeking out a man running away with 2 million dollars. I found myself practically holding my breath whenever Llewelyn encountered Anton.

Roger Deakins' iconic cinematography looks gorgeous and haunting with dark night and bright lights everywhere. His angles and framing for each gun barrel, man running, to locks getting blown out by air are breathtaking. I love Deakin's wide shot of Josh Brolin running over the sand dune away from the truck with blaring headlights at midnight. Joel and Ethan Coen's editing sharps cuts from ultra wide outdoors shots to indoor guns blasting with shocking efficiency. Their smart cuts and beguiling editing enthralled me for all 122 minutes of No Country for Old Men.

Joel and Ethan Coen's reflective writing and patience for the elderly feeling overwhelmed in a desolate wasteland with morality. Cormac McCarthy's nihilistic writing style is fully on display as Joel and Ethan adapt McCarthy's novel No Country for Old Men. McCarthy writes killers with no conscience, who wear down the police trying to capture them with their senseless killing. 

No Country for Old Men depicts the brutal realism of random people dying for no good reason and how depressing that looks. From a fearsome assassination, who relentlessly guns down all witnesses in his path, to a man desiring the wealth he's stumbled onto, to the sheriff out of his depth despite his years of experience. Tommy Lee Jones is amazing as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell with his shred observations and quick wit. Jones feels like he understands Bell's devastation at realizing old men cannot compete with the neverending hordes of evil that plague America with bloody crimes. Age and wisdom account for only so much when fighting against monsters.

Joel Coen's direction for his neo-noir Western No Country for Old Men (2007) is enthralling in every second. The Coen Brothers have achieved the remarkable in directing a fun and violent Western for contemporary audiences that does not feel old fashioned. Joel and Ethan Coen's writing is pithy and revealing, while the characters are unique types all their own. It is a slow burn like all Westerns, so you are going to have a good time watching No Country for Old Men.

I must mention the stellar acting from Josh Brolin, Javier Bardem, and Tommy Lee Jones in particular. You will really feel like you have an understanding of who these men are at heart. They are memorable and complex characters that are a pleasure to watch perform. Josh Brolin is gripping with a nuanced lead role as welder and Vietnam veteran Llewelyn Moss, with his nervous face awaiting his pursuers with his sawed off shotgun. 

Whereas the impeccable performance from Javier Bardem is terrifying as he delivers one of the greatest villains in cinema as his stoic sociopath Anton Chigurh on the loose. His every moment feels intentional and compassionless. His cruel killings make No Country for Old Men a visceral experience. Woody Harrelson is excellent as Carson Wells, who seems smarter than he really is as you can never see your fate coming.

Tommy Lee Jones is entertaining as the hardened Sheriff Ed Tom Bell searching for these men. Garrett Dillahunt is funny as the stupid and simple minded deputy Wendell. Tess Harper is thoughtful and attentive as Ed Tom Bell's wife Loretta Bell. Barry Corbin gives a fantastic and poignant monologue about the pointlessness of fighting for justice in a cruel world with violent men. Stephen Root is fun as the tough businessman hired by the Cartel to hire Anton Chigurh and Carson Wells. Beth Grant's complaints as Carla Jean's elderly mother, who cannot stand the way things are is perfectly in line with No Country for Old Men's themes. Ana Reeder's cameo as the flirty girl by the pool is funny.

I adored seeing the ethereal Scottish actress Kelly Macdonald as her Southern drawl accent is flawless. I felt so bad for her innocent Carla Jean Moss. She's wonderful alongside Josh Brolin as they have realistic chemistry on screen. Her phenomenal natural acting makes for a delightful viewing until her sorrowful final scene with Javier Bardem. No Country for Old Men is certainly perfectly cast. You can even see a young Caleb Landry Jones before Get Out as the boy on his bike at the end astonished by Anton's bone.

Furthermore, I feel like in addition to No Country for Old Men's steady pace, the complete lack of music gives a sparse and empty feeling. Sound designers Skip Lievsay, Craig Berkey, Peter F. Kurland, and Greg Orloff hit you with each gunshot and gentle footstep. Alongside No Country for Old Men's steady pace, the subtle sound editing gives a sparse feeling. You are stunned with the minimalism of silence as you are witnessing quiet homicide with Anton's air gun over and over again. Carter Burwell is credited as composer, but only has a nice end credits song as the quiet in No Country for Old Men is very unsettling and builds atmosphere with an ever growing disquiet. There's no upfront score to be sure.

Mary Zophres came up with all these cool cowboy costumes alongside her fellow costume designers Lori DeLapp and Lisanne Scafine. Jean Ann Black's make-up gives everyone a natural, sweaty look, except for Javier Bardem in a ghastly wig that makes him all the more uncanny to gaze upon in horror. Jess Gonchor's production design and Nancy Haigh's set decoration ensures Texas, New Mexico, and Mexico look as impoverished and gritty as possible. John P. Goldsmith's art direction is lovely with dogs swimming down river to headlights shining through the darkest nights in No Country for Old Men.

Overall, No Country for Old Men is worth watching over and over again. It is the best neo-noir style neo-Western movie to come out in the 2,000's really. I would also recommend The Big Lebowski and Fargo from The Coen Brothers if you end up liking No Country for Old Men. For more modern Western movies, check out Hell or High Water, The Revenant, or Wind River.

This haunting and eerie tale about a stone-cold psychopath on a manhunt for the 'misunderstood' protagonist is executed perfectly. Exquisite storytelling along with outstanding acting gives the audience a reason to keep watching even with its lengthy runtime. And although some moments seem lacking importance to the plot, the audience remains on the edge of their seats due to the Coens' brothers excellent manipulation of suspense.

But at the same time it harkens back to the roots of cinema, recalling Hitchcock and Leone, and Welles's Touch of Evil, as a combination of the best of noir and westerns. There are so many exceptional shots and lighting, so much depth to the perception of the characters through the mis-en-scene, so much tension, that through this it's all up to the actors to make or break the near-perfection that is the McCarthy source. Bardem embodies Anton like no other could: you can't even look into his eyes without wincing, often steel-cold and horrifically professional (to what profession... who can say?). Josh Brolin and Tommy Lee Jones are also fantastic; we see Brolin often in the midst of an action scene, a moment of 'save-your-life' going on, and one can finally see an actor of his caliber completely breaking out in a role that doesn't require him to ever totally "emote". Jones, on the other hand, gives a compassionate turn in a film that's about the struggles of desperate men in a land without law and order. He's gone through so much that it comes out completely in his voice and eyes, sorrowful but holding back, and he reaches a level of connection with the character that makes the Fugitive look like simpleton TV. Kelly McDonald, who plays Lleland's wife, is also excellent when called upon, especially in a crucial scene later in the film.

No Country for Old Men is directed by the Coen Brothers (Fargo, The Big Lebowski) and stars Javier Bardem as Anton Chigurh, a deadly and stalking killer hunting down Josh Brolin's character Llewelyn Moss who has stolen $2,000,000 in drug money.

The good? This is my favourite Coen Brothers film (so far), which isn't saying much as I haven't liked any of their picture's so far, keep in mind I've only seen a few. That is not a diversion from a recommendation however, No Country for Old Men is a successfully thrilling movie. Let's start with Javier Bardem, his performance is uncanny now in modern movie villainy and I fully understand why. His looming, eerie, intimidating presence caused major laps of full heart-in-chest moments by yours truly. A character delved with such mysterious creativity, who makes an oxygen tank of all things look like a AK-47 assault rifle. Josh Brolin acts well as Llewelyn Moss, you enjoy watching the predator, Anton, stalk his quick prey. No Country for Old Men may as well be silent, because the more intriguing and uncomfortable parts are set with no dialogue, just visual shock and skill. The Coen Brothers know how to set out a starting atmosphere in which nothing seems to be surviving, like a zombie apocalypse has just broken out. The key substance to the film is a bit iffy, but from what i could delve, it seems to try and push a hint that death is inescapable when living in a land of crime, drugs and money.

The bad? No Country for Old Men may be my favourite (so far) but it isn't an amazing movie. I found Tommy Lee Jone's character, Ed Tom Bell, to be unnecessary to the main man vs man survival situation. Adding no essence to what is otherwise a densely packed, realistically set thriller. In addition, the dialogue is droll for the most part. With the exception of Bardem's 'coin toss' exchange, a lot of scenes seemed to be set out just to falsely trick the audience into having some sort of relevance to anything that was happening. Oh, and please don't intrude Woody Harrelson into the movie halfway through, what a waste of a character and an actor. He seems to be a last minute icing on the cake to join two disjointed plots. Sad. Finally, the conclusion is left half-assed and stranded at it's peak of interest. Like they gave up or something.

All in all, I still recommend No Country for Old Men because it's moments of terror are worth watching just to feel your blood rushing through your skin, and an award worthy performance from Javier Bardem, seriously understandable praise of the highest order. Have your 'pee-breaks' whenever the movie switches to something you feel isn't fundamental, dangerous or putting you to sleep. You'll notice when it comes....Friendo.

Llewelyn Moss is a Vietnam veteran who comes across a drug deal gone wrong while he´s hunting in the middle of a Texas desert, he finds a case with 2 million dollars in it and decides to keep the money. Moss doesn't know that his naïve action makes him the primarily target of a psychotic hitman that will stop at nothing in order to reclaim the money. When you make an adaptation of a book/novel, there are two directions that you could go with: Modifying some segments of the source material in order to fulfill a 2-3hr runtime or you could try to make an adaptation as faithful to the source material as possible, the Coen brothers decided to take their adaptation of Cormac McCarthy´s novel into the second type of direction.  "No Country for Old Men" is an extremely well made film filled with greatness: The performances are solid with Javier Bardem stealing the film in a unforgettable performance as a creepy, calculating and bloodthirsty hitman; the story is extremely simple but is executed perfectly, a spot on pacing, memorable sequences, a surprising mixture of various genres (drama, action, thriller and even western), the Coen´s trademark black humor and over the top violence is here in little doses, Joel and Ethan´s directing is focused on the details, the narrative just throws you into this world and connects the lives of our three main characters in a credible way, a perfect amount of ambiguity, beautiful cinematography that perfectly creates a western style, a fantastic use of multiple themes, an impeccable use of dialog when it is absolutely needed, and the whole film feels not only as a feature movie but also like poetry as the conclusion comes closer. My only big problem with this film is the conclusion itself, it may be the same that the novel had and it concludes Moss quest of trying to literally outrun the devil in an appropriate way but it is also somewhat disappointing and lackluster for a film that had built up to its conclusion with such precision.
"No Country for Old Men" is an intense and unforgettable film that maybe the Coen´s finest work, but with the resume they have is extremely hard to pick, my runner-up film of 2007.

Filming on the bleak, seemingly infinite deserts of Texas and New Mexico, the Coen brothers accomplished the impossible: the filming of a Cormac McCarthy novel. The movie opens with our protagonist, Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin), stumbling upon the striking wreckage of a drug deal done gone awry, and finding a briefcase containing 2 million dollars. Attempting to make this money his own, Llewelyn takes the briefcase and unknowingly sets off an unstoppable chain of violence, as he is tracked down by the ruthless Anton Chigurh, played by Javier Bardem.

The performances in No Country for Old Men are spectacular, especially that of Bardem. Anton Chigurh embodies pure, brutal evil so convincingly, that at times it is hard to remember that Bardem is just acting.  The film offers amazing visuals and elements of a heart-pounding thriller, while also feeling like a character study of Moss and Chigurh. The film is also incredibly focused, with almost every sentence uttered by the characters feeling intriguing and important to the progression of the story.

One of the most interesting and effective tools used by the Coen brothers throughout the movie is the usage of silence. The film completely lacks any cinematic music or soundtrack, allowing the dead, yet piercing silence to take over some of the most suspenseful moments, making them more spine-tingling than any music ever could. 

Ultimately, No Country is an incredibly suspenseful, thought-provoking, and thrilling ride with incredible direction by Joel and Ethan Coen to bring the novel to life.

Review In A Nutshell:

Boy, how wrong I was about this film, claiming before that this was one of the Coen brothers' weaker films. It was almost a year ago since I have first viewed No Country For Old Men and since then I have learned so much about the directors and cinema as a whole, and through this growth I was able to gain a better appreciation of this film. I previously watched this at a time where it was late at night, expecting something great but nothing difficult; I found myself dozing off frequently during this film, finding it to be uneventful and lacking of drama. It is only now that I have watched this film at a time where I am more alert and a stage in my life where I could appreciate darker and more thought provoking films.

No Country For Old Men opens up with a Texas desert that feels empty and grim, supported by a narration that fleshes out the backdrops and its characters without becoming too specific, whilst listening we are treated to a visual introduction of the antagonist, committing a brutal and relentless murder that would then shape the silent menacing tone of the film. The film speaks about its themes of violence, greed and morality in such a way that looks slightly exaggerated but feels harrowingly honest. Its central protagonist, Llewelyn, stumbles upon a drug deal gone wrong and allowed him to struck gold, finding a suitcase full of cash, and decides to keep it for himself. This gave us a glimpse of what humanity has become, linking it to the aftermath of the Vietnam war with constant references on it spoken here and there, losing a sense of virtue and relying on their armoury to protect themselves from those that are greedier than their own; this idea of greed seems to be a recurring theme for the brothers with it being prominent in their earlier films including Fargo and The Big Lebowski. The film also explores upon the idea of morality, showing that goodness has slowly faded in the souls of the people, with only those that are passionately violent and strong-willed will survive, and this tragedy of the human soul is enriched upon the perspective of lawman Ed Tom Bell, who states at the start of the film this at the start of the film. The Coen brothers emphasise this through the minimisation of using extras to fill the environment, allowing it to create that sense of emptiness that connects effectively with the film's themes. It is only at the end, where Bell shares two dreams he had about his father where I felt lost, unable to make the connection with the film's themes due to its ambiguity.

The Coen brothers have shifted their playful quality into something that is much dire and serious, and I think the decision to do this allowed the film's themes and ideas to create more impact to the viewers; creating that sense of unpredictability that leaves viewers feel tense and fearful. What is more frightening is that the directors do not hold back in showing gruesome images, letting the camera be right there as it is happening. The film may follow three different characters, but each one is given a generous amount of time to be followed, with Javier Bardem's character as the deadly and arbitrary Anton Chigurh. In his travels, we see him encounter individuals, sometimes random, and for the bulk of it he tortures them psychologically, giving them a feeling of danger without actually showing it or making it plainly obvious, and it is through this foreplay that the audience could easily feel uneasy and when he does pounce and strike, it is then when we feel terror. The film however, does not over-exaggerate the character, especially when it comes to its physical appearance; there is something darkly comical about his notable and peculiar haircut and the usage of a high-pressure oxygen tank to murder his victims; practical but no doubt unorthodox. The rest of the central characters look and feel much more grounded but in saying they never at all came across as dull or generic.

In my initial experience with the film, I was bugged by the fact that it lacked musical score, as it allowed the more mundane moments feel more tedious than they already are. It is only now that I am able to appreciate the effect that this silence was able to create in regards to its story, ideas, characters, and atmosphere. It is this lack of sonic activity do we feel uneasy when watching threatening events unfold, aiding the feeling of unpredictability that no doubt runs throughout the film. No Country For Old Men never aimed to be a dramatic piece or a crime-driven film; it attempts to capture something real, something that we could see or feel in our own reality and future. The thought of it frightens me but I guess there is nothing much that we could do about it.

No Country For Old Men has taken its time to grow on me, but that was only because then I lacked the required awareness and understanding to appreciate something that is as dark and painfully honest as this. No Country For Old Men is an example of cinema at its finest.

Dark, grim, bleak, hopeless and strangely comic, yep, it's a Cormac McCarthy story. Perfectly brought to the screen by The Coen Brothers, No Country for Old Men is a very cold thriller that features top-notch performances from Brolin, Bardem and Jones.

I haven't read the book, which is something I've said I wouldn't do anymore, but this film, at least from what I've read others say, does follow the book almost perfectly and considering the themes of the story and how everything unfolds, I'm inclined to believe what I've read, which is a huge positive but also somewhat of a negative but I'll save that for later. 

So much happens in this film that I'm still surprised that it was only 2 hours but it is welcome, so many films released around Oscar season tend to go far too long. The Coens are perfect directors, they know how to create the perfect sense of dread and tension, at any moment I felt like something was about to go wrong, they know how to set everything up perfectly and it is brilliant to watch. The film flew by so fast because I was so invested in what was going on in a quite simple story that has many layers to it. It's crazy how honestly simple the story is but wonders are done with it, with the talents of McCarthy's novel and the Coen's direction it wasn't hard to expect great things. 

The acting in this is outstanding, Brolin, Bardem and Jones are at the top of their respective games here and I wish that they all walked away with Oscar nominations. The cinematography is absolutely beautiful and everything just looks very crisp and raw, it's beautiful to look at and once again Roger Deakins is ignored. Surprisingly, the film has a sense of humor, albeit a very dark sense of humor but it fit unbelievably well. It's a neo-western story and it very much feels like one, the whole thing is a Wild West story taking place in a modern-ish age. 

It isn't perfect though, something happens about 30 minutes before the end that was quite questionable. While it didn't annoy me as I appreciated a smarter, more philosophical approach, I'm just surprised that it isn't in the critics consensus or that more critics haven't commented on it (but it wouldn't be a cinematic masterpiece, then, would it?). This ending that we got is probably more welcome than if it went the conventional action route, which probably would have gotten a mention in the critics consensus, it's just that some things that work in one type of media don't translate well to film, especially when you disregard a main character, who has had a massive scenario building up this whole time, right at the last minute. Movie Review: No Country for Old Men by Charles Firth

No Country for Old Men is not about drug dealing or cowboys or deserts or hit men. These are the trappings in which a grand story is set -- a story that deals with archetypes, questions of morality, meaning and destiny.

The Cohen brothers have created a cinematic masterpiece interpreting the same-named novel written by Cormac McCarthy, the Pulitzer Prize and National Book Award winning author. The brothers bring the story to film true-to-spirit, albeit with some editing for length and one noticeable character deviation which seems to be the result of their own philosophical prejudice (see Carla Jean's coin toss below).

In his book, McCarthy creates a paradoxical reality in which murderers are the only self-examined and morally consistent inhabitants. The seemingly innocent are doomed by virtue of their own philosophical and moral inconsistency.

In the book, and less so in the film, each chapter is prefaced with a narrative that, at first glance, appears to encapsulate the story's philosophical premise - that the world is going to hell in a hand basket. Yet in the end, this narrative amounts to nothing more than a kind of pervasive exasperation with the events that unfold and the world at large. The narrator, Sheriff Ed Tom Bell, defies the typical role of narrator. Narrators generally provide direction, context, even omniscience. But here, Sheriff Tom (Tommy Lee Jones) offers only bewilderment, expressed in between Texas colloquialisms that hint at a deep, yet unfulfilled, search for the truth.

McCarthy and the Cohens immediately throw us off the track, setting up a gruff cowboy, Llewellyn Moss, as the likely protagonist. Moss, as it turns out, is not our classic protagonist. He is simply a pawn, a failed man, doomed to suffer the consequence of his own moral corruption. He chooses to hoard manna over compassion for another human being -- even over the safety of his nubile and unquestioning wife Carla Jean (played to a "T" by Kelly Macdonald). But like the biblical manna, which also appeared in the desert, hoarding it again corrupts.

Moss is given more than one chance to redeem himself. When confronted by the film's guardian angel Carson Wells, complete with white hat and played with Texan precision by Woody Harrelson (think: a drawling Clarence from "It's a Wonderful Life"), he scoffs, insults and refuses what would appear to be divine intervention to save his doe-eyed Carla Jean. 

But the film is bounded by a universal law of justice, as doled out by our arch antagonist turned protagonist, Anton Chigurh. He is the character who continues to push the action forward. But is he the angel of death? Is he fate? No, it turns out he is simply a force of nature -- a probability become absolute certainty in the quantum-collapsed-wave now moment. Once you have seen Anton, there is no going back. And only those who violate Anton's internally consistent sense of justice need see him. 

Chigurh, or "Sugar" as Moss blasphemously refers to him, is the final curtain for those who cross him. And those who cross him always seem to underestimate him to the same degree that they under-examine their own lives. But seeing Chigurh is not a guaranteed ticket to the beyond. Some get a second chance by way of a coin toss, others are simply innocents passed over for another day. Yet others only have to run into Chigurh with their car to make the journey into the beyond.

What is it that McCormick is trying to tell us? A message that the Cohens so deftly bring to the silver screen... Is it Nihilism? Existentialism? Predestination? Or is he simply telling us that unless we examine our own lives and live with moral consistency we will never be able to make sense of the outer world? A world that appears to Sherrif Tom as full of ever escalating violence, corruption and chaos? 

What remains consistent throughout the story is Chiguhr's sense of justice and his sense of connection to what he believes is universal law. Everyone else is compromised. In the book we learn that Ed Tom abandoned his post and his men in WWII and is forever attempting to compensate for this primary moral failing. Llewellyn abandons a dying man and his wife when he could have saved both. 

Even Ed Tom's wife abandons the outside world by never reading the news or watching TV. Carla Jean abandons reality via blind, unexamined faith. In the film, she refuses Chigurh's offer of a coin toss. In the book she accepts, leaving her fate seemingly to fate. But the toss changes nothing. As Chigurh explains, he is there for a reason. He arrived, "the same way the coin did."

Chigurh reminds us, it is our decisions, made each day, one after another which bring us to this place we are in, in the present moment. And God help us if that place is sitting across from Anton Chigurh and his pressure-driven cattle gun -- just another dumb animal ready for the slaughter.

The Coen Brothers and Cormac McCarthy may not have much else to say, but for your attention, they need not say much else. If anything, it may be better to interpret No Country for Old Men as a horror-thriller, than as a neo-Western drama. The Coen Brothers are of the course the main men behind this excellent production and direct and write this as well if the best they have ever done in there movie career. This one requires quite a bit of thought and reflection after it in order to figure out what you think happened and if it was good or not. This film is a tough one to digest. The trailer and the whole set up of the film makes it appear to be a western thriller with a villain chasing a hero, pursued by a supporting hero, and you expect the hero to come out on top with the help of the law-maker. But this is a Coen Bros movie. It doesn't work that way. Our villain isn't just a villain. He's a ghost, a phantom, a representation of evil. He doesn't conform to villain plots. Our hero thinks he is on top of things, but he does not understand exactly what he is doing. Our supporting hero is old and broken. Even our damsel in distress is no damsel, but distress is certainly at hand. 
If you like a film to build up plots and then have pay offs in a big, interlocking ending, then this film is not for you. Be prepared to question what it all means and be prepared for an ending that has no high points, no final showdown, no pay off. Just be prepared for a gritty, well written, well directed and brilliant but challenging film.

I reckon Westerns deal mostly with physics. You got your forces and your stationary objects. Your forces are the good guys, and they have to move the objects, which are the bad guys, and then the movie's ended well. The question No Country for Old Men raises is, what if your object is equal to your force?

Javier Bardem supplies the object, a hitman who operates on a code that is always merciless and often sadistic, and is terrifying in the role. Josh Brolin is a cowboy that defies the object. If he can simply move it, he stands to profit immensely. If he can't, he loses everything. And so he'll do whatever it takes to move it. Woody Harrelson is a bounty hunter opposing the object. He moves it because that's his job. Kelly MacDonald is Brolin's wife, who refuses to play by the object's rules. If she doesn't accept it, maybe it doesn't exist. And Tommy Lee (playing a man instead of a cartoon, as he is so often cast in his age), well, he's the sheriff, who says this at the outset:

"There was this boy I sent to the 'lectric chair at Huntsville here awhile back. My arrest and my testimony. He killt a 14 year-old girl. Papers said it was a crime of passion but he told me there wasn't any passion to it.... Said that if they turned him out, he'd do it again. Said he knew he was going to hell: 'Be there in about fifteen minutes.' I don't know what to make of that. I surely don't."

What if your object is equal to your force? That question is No Country for Old Men.

No Country For Old Men follows the same footsteps as the Coen Brothers previous just as dark and witty drama Fargo. But that is where the a likenesses stop because unlike Fargo, No Country For Old Men manages to thrill the audience on an even higher scale. It sees a small town sheriff Ed Tom Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) attempting to prevent the likely demise of a hunter Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin) who stumbles upon a drug deal gone wrong and more than two million dollars in cash near the Rio Grande. Which happily leads to Javier Bardem. A ruthless, psychopathic hitman that wants Moss in the palms of his hands. So does this film seem simple enough to you. I mean, it is a cat and mouse chase film, that in small places reminds us of the Terminator but how simple this film may appear it certainly does one thing. It stands out from the crowd, with its exceptional writing and directing, this film is a flawless adaption of Cormac McCarthy's Novel. I don't think there is another screenwriter or director that can touch what the Coen Brothers have achieved here, however saying that we do have Quentin Tarantino for Pulp Fiction, but you get the picture. In No Country For Old Men, it is very much like a battle between Heaven and Hell, with one man caught in the middle. That man being Moss. With the four Oscars this film managed to achieve Javier held his Oscar up high with his supporting role as Anton Chigurh. Which maybe I wouldn't go as far to say it is deserved but it was certainly earned. 

To say that Chigurh isn't a character is faulty. It's like saying the film is beautiful except that, that and that. Just because Chigurh doesn't act with the same motivations of other movie killers, doesn't mean he isn't a character. As one great man said just because you are a character, doesn't mean you have character. Chigurh represents something more. You could even say he is the Hannibal Lector of the crowd with his random questions and subjects of conversations, not to mention his strong psychopathic nature. Chigurh is often referred by peers (not friends) as 'crazy', which is accurate but surly there is more to him than that, isn't there? He has a very easy mind but remains strong and firm against the moving world surrounding him. He clearly works solo and it doesn't feel that he works for anyone (Well I don't think he does anyway). He doesn't get angry when his life is in serious danger but more annoyed and frustrated when Moss' wife won't call heads or tails or when a receptionist won't tell him where Moss works. We see him toying and having fun with people, like the clerk at a gas station who married a wife who was into the gas station business. The interesting thing about this confrontation is you see that Chigurh isn't only just a killer, but he's not afraid to tell it like it is. 

I can genuinely say No Country For Old Men is one of my favourite films of this decade if not of all time and a clear Oscar grabber as its great writing, great acting and superb directing ensures that. However to fully appreciate this film it needs to be viewed several times but that's okay because it deserves to be seen more than once. Verdict: Films don't get much better and sophisticated as this and even though it is a cat and mouse chase film it certainly isn't predicable and has surprises around every corner. The Coen brothers' No Country for Old Men is one of the best films they have ever made, and Cormac McCarthy's novel gives them the perfect setting for their stories of chaos in this seemingly normal world. The story involves 3 different men in search of the same thing, but for different reasons, which is a plot that resembles Leone's The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. However, this is more of a western fable that deals with the moral decadence of society. Anton, Llewellyn, and Tom are the main characters searching for the money that was left behind at a drug deal gone bad. Anton is evil, he's played by Javier Bardem, who gives an amazing performance, Anton is searching for the money not so much because he's greedy, but because he thinks it belongs to him. And he will kill almost anyone who gets in the way of that, but he has what you can call principles, which really just means he kills only when it seems to have value for him. Llewellyn wants the money basically because he found it, and it's money, so he's not gonna give it up. And Tom is the only one searching for the money with honest reasons, he is the sheriff trying to put an end to Anton's blood trail, and the best way to end it is to get what is the cause of it. All these characters perfectly demonstrate where our ambitions have gone, how far our vanity has gone, and where our morals used to reside. This really is one of the most well written, directed, acted, and photographed of all the Coens' films. It is paced like a thriller, photographed like a western, and written like the Coens' brand of noir, which makes for a super entertaining film with much more depth than the average film. No Country for Old Men is a film that no one should miss, and every film buff should have multiple viewings of.

I expect a film like 'No Country for Old Men' to be polarizing for some, especially if they're expecting a big finale with the good guy and the bad guy drawing their guns in the end to settle the score. 'No Country for Old Men' is a film that dabbles more in existentialism, despite all the crime that occurs. Basically, what I'm saying is that the film adapted from the novel is very unconventional not only for its genre, but also in its approach to storytelling. What the Coen brothers do best is combining altogether different elements and creating something with its own unique character. While there are subtle throwbacks to the old wild west, the story takes place in modern society where technology has advanced, society has advanced and unfortunately crime has too.

What are Anton Chigurh's true motives? Does he have a philosophical doctrine that we the audience are unaware of or are just unable to comprehend? What Anton does is create alot of questions that arise from his actions and his interactions with the other characters. To watch a character as odd as him is fascinating and I cannot give enough credit to Javier Bardem in portraying such a character that is so enigmatic and just his presence alone is able to evoke so much mystery. Even though Anton is very incomprehensive, it is all made up for by being able to be somehow captivated by him.

How every character deals with Anton is interesting, to say the least and as the film progresses, the feeling of despondency increases gradually. The lack of heroes is what gives this film its sense of hopelessness and that feeling of hopelessness is basically set in stone from the first few shots coupled with Tommy Lee Jone's epic voiceover narration in introducing the story. It is the perfect introduction to what we will witness in the story and what it all means for a sheriff like him in comprehending these events. As the events occur, we the audience reflect on these situations just as much as Sheriff Ed Tom Bell. Tommy Lee Jones' performance in this role is impressive and is injected with a great sense of humanity. I commend his portrayal as Bell, in that he is the character who carries the weight of the story.

The acting is a huge fragment in bringing this film to life, but what also does that is how the visuals are executed and it is definitely utilized to a great effect. From its majestic shots to its beautiful lighting and color tones, the Coen brothers set a mood that permeates the whole film. Its barren settings really add a feeling of desolation that is at the same time hypnotic and surreal. While the film can be suspenseful and its suspense is definitely executed perfectly, the film still somehow manages to maintain an air of mystique. The non-existence of a soundtrack really gives the film a feeling of loneliness, all the while adding an even greater sense of sterility to its already barren wasteland.

I can go on and on about the great acting, its memorable shots and its great script, but what makes 'No Country' a great film is that it manages to be truly idiosyncratic in its execution just like how the Coen Brothers' other great films are. Even if a film like this leaves me more questions than answers, if it still manages to captivate me to a point that I'm willing to return to it, then that shows that it doesn't matter if I don't have any answers to my questions. There are only a few films that are able to pull this off naturally and 'No Country for Old Men' is definitely one of those special films that can do just that.

Most thrillers maybe entertaining but 'No Country For Old Men' invites its audiences right into the story, creating an incredibly tense, clever piece topped with black humour on the side.

The film follows, in essence, a bag full of two million dollars after it is taken by a Vietnam veteran, played by Josh Brolin in what must surely rank as his greatest role. He is tracked down by Anton Chigurh, a psychotic hired killer across Texas as the chain reaction escalates.

Adapted from a Cormac McCarthy novel, fast becoming a Coen favourite, the brother directors take on a classic crime style story but add their own fantastical style.

Javier Bardem is almost perfect in the film, playing opposite the brilliant Brolin, whilst Tommy Lee Jones strange part in the story is carefully and gently crafted by an excellent performance from Jones.

But every component of the film is mastered to a particular thriller style, in a very Coen way. The normalities of any Coen piece are there, with the memorable storyline, complicated twists and turns and well above average cinematography. However the enticing poetic nature of the film is what makes it stand above the rest and pull you ever deeper into the character's lives, both normal and abnormal.

And what to say of the action sequences themselves? Superb, as well as never losing sight of the basic plot and using wonderful characterisation.

The plot itself is complicated and the end of the film, whilst panned by some, is actually devilishly clever and a fantastic ending. Its supposed ambiguity may frustrate some, although when you watch for a second time the majority of the ambiguity washes away.

The Coen's brother collection of films make it hard to point definitely to just one as their unchallenged masterpiece, but in the ranks of their greatest films, as well as some of the finest cinema to come out of America in years, 'No Country For Old Men' ranks at the top.

Para piorar, o desenvolvimento do filme é carregado de falhas. Chega a ser patético o fato do bandido Chigurh (Javier Bardem) encontrar Llewelyn Moss (Josh Brolin), o portador da maleta, em qualquer lugar. No início, tal fato é justificável devido a maleta ter um localizador escondido, mas e depois que o mesmo é descoberto e retirado dela? Sem falar que estou até agora sem entender a parte em que Moss esconde a maleta no duto ventilação de um hotel e depois pega outro quarto, fazendo uma tremenda gambiarra para retirá-la. Lembrando que até essa cena ele não sabia da existência do localizador. Outra interrogação que ficou em minha cabeça foi: por que diabos uns assassinatos são mostrados e outros não? Se o objetivo foi o de tornar a trama mais complexa, não funcionou. E a maneira pela qual o veterano Xerife Ed Tom Bell (Tommy Lee Jones) é inserida na história, leva o espectador a questionar sua competência, chegando atrasado nas cenas dos crimes e sem falar que, em certo momento, ele vê os bandidos fugindo e prefere parar para ver o que aconteceu do que persegui-los.


Mas há também muitos pontos positivos na obra dos Coen. O mais destacável é a magistral atuação de Javier Bardem, que dá um tom assustador ao seu mitológico personagem, e faz muitos estragos apenas com um tubo de pressão para matar gado. A interpretação de Bardem e a caracterização de seu personagem faz o mesmo entrar na lista dos melhores vilões da história do cinema. O Oscar de melhor ator coadjuvante foi merecidissimo ao contrário dos outros 3 que o longa foi premiado. Falando em atuações, é sempre muito bom ter Tommy Lee Jones no elenco. Aqui, apesar de achar que o mesmo foi mal aproveitado, sua presença dá um charme a mais. Josh Brolin dá para o gasto, em uma atuação que não exige muito. O filme também contém alguns, digo alguns, diálogos interessantes e reflexivos. E quando existe o nome de Roger Deakins envolvido numa produção é certeza que temos uma fotografia magnífica e aqui, colabora para aumentar o tom sombrio e de suspense em algumas cenas. A mais memorável delas é a que Moss está em um hotel, percebe que Chigurh está lá, apaga a luz e fica com a arma apontada para a porta, observando os vultos do corredor pela soleira. Esses pontos salvam a produção do pior.


Quando o filme acaba (e por sinal o final é muito fraco), ficamos com a sensação de que "Onde Os Fracos Não tem Vez" poderia ter sido bem melhor. O rascunho é excelente, apesar da historinha clichê, mas contém furos gritantes de desenvolvimento. Existem detalhes no cinema que podem ser ignorados com facilidade e infelizmente isso não acontece aqui.
Talvez, o mais decepcionante foi ver este ganhar de "Sangue Negro" na disputa pelo Oscar de melhor filme. Definitivamente, a principal premiação de cinema do mundo não serve mais como referência de qualidade.
